Engineering hollow core-shell hetero-structure box to induce interfacial charge modulation for promoting bidirectional sulfur conversion in lithium-sulfur batteries Weiliang Zhou 1 Xinying Wang 1 Jiongwei Shan 1 Liguo Yue Dongzhen Lu Li Chen Jiacheng Zhang Yunyong Li ⁎ School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, No. 100 Waihuan Xi Road, Guangzhou Higher Education Mega Center, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China School of Materials and Energy Guangdong University of Technology No. 100 Waihuan Xi Road, Guangzhou Higher Education Mega Center Guangzhou 510006 Guangdong China School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, No. 100 Waihuan Xi Road, Guangzhou Higher Education Mega Center, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Hollow CoO@CoP-Box core–shell heterostructures as models and multifunctional catalysts modified on separators were developed, and its atomic-level mechanism for inducing interfacial charge modulation and more active sites was uncovered. Severe polysulfide shuttling and sluggish sulfur redox kinetics significantly decrease sulfur utilization and cycling stability in lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs). Herein, we develop a hollow CoO/CoP-Box core–shell heterostructure as a model and multifunctional catalyst modified on separators to induce interfacial charge modulation and expose more active sites for promoting the adsorption and catalytic conversion ability of sulfur species. Theoretical and experimental findings verify that the in-situ formed core–shell hetero-interface induces the formation of P-Co-O binding and charge redistribution to activate surface O active sites for binding lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) via strong Li-O bonding, thus strongly adsorbing with LiPSs. Meanwhile, the strong Li-O bonding weakens the competing Li-S bonding in LiPSs or Li2S adsorbed on CoO/CoP-Box surface, plus the hollow heterostructure provides abundant active sites and fast electron/Li+ transfer, so reducing Li2S nucleation/dissolution activation energy. As expected, LSBs with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator and traditional sulfur/carbon black cathode display a large initial capacity of 1240 mA h g−1 and a long cycling stability with 300 cycles (∼60.1% capacity retention) at 0.5C. Impressively, the thick sulfur cathode (sulfur loading: 5.2 mg cm−2) displays a high initial areal capacity of 6.9 mA h cm−2. This work verifies a deep mechanism understanding and an effective strategy to induce interfacial charge modulation and enhance active sites for designing efficient dual-directional Li-S catalysts via engineering hollow core–shell hetero-structure. Keywords CoO/CoP-Box Hollow core–shell hetero-structure Multifunctional catalysts Interfacial charge modulation Lithium sulfur batteries 1 Introduction There is an urgent need to design a high energy storage system in a constrained space because of the recent increase in the development of electronic devices and electric cars [1–4]. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are the one of most promising options in the development of next-generation energy storage systems because of their high specific energy, plentiful storage capacity (sulfur), and environmental friendliness [5–7]. However, due to the dissolution of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and the slow conversion kinetics (Li2S n to Li2S, 4 ≤ n ≤ 8), a variety of issues brought by the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs hamper the development of LSBs for practical applications [8–10]. An efficient strategy is to prevent the dissolution of LiPSs using polar molecules with high adsorption capacity, such as oxides, sulfides, and phosphides [11]. It has been demonstrated that these polar molecules interact strongly with the surface polar sites of sulfur, thereby trapping LiPSs through chemical bonding [12]. Due to differences in the distribution conversion rates during sulfur redox, it is noteworthy that the conversion rate of S8 to Li2S n (3 ≤ n ≤ 8) is significantly faster than that of the decomposition from Li2S n to Li2S. This suggests that it plays a limited role in decreasing the accumulation of Li2S n if just relying on the capture of polar compounds [13–15]. It is possible to successfully reduce the accumulation of Li2S n and thereby to prevent its shuttle by enhancing the conversion kinetics of Li2S n . Therefore, it is critical to design a polar catalyst for effectively balancing and accelerating the catalytic conversion kinetics from S8 to Li2S. Recently, some highly active catalysts have been gradually introduced to LSBs with impressive results [16]. Examples include phosphides [17,18], selenides [19], nitrides [20], and sulfides [21], which significantly improve the kinetics of LiPSs and reduce the LiPS shuttling. Among them, phosphides have good electronic conductivity, moderate polysulfide adsorption capacity, and high catalytic conversion ability. Currently, the construction of heterogeneous structures by combining adsorbents with strong adsorption ability and catalysts with efficient catalytic reactivity can effectively enhance the “trapping-diffusion-conversion” process [22–24], and it is thought to be a viable approach to overcome the aforementioned issues [25,26]. Additionally, Li-S catalysis is governed by the adsorption capacity and effective active area (active site) of the catalysts. As a result, the structural design of catalysts should be a major determinant of their catalytic activity. Catalysts with strong adsorption and high specific surface area are better able to capture and catalyze LiPSs [27–29]. In contrast to other nanostructures, hollow nanostructures have drawn a lot of attention due to their exceptional qualities, including their significant surface area, high number of catalytically active sites, and short diffusion distances for both active species and electron transport [30–32]. The conversion and anchoring of polysulfide intermediates can be significantly sped up by CoP nanoparticles in hollow polyhedral/carbon nanotube superstructures (CoP@HPCN) superstructures. Despite the fact that there are more research findings on CoP in various applications such as electrocatalysis in LSBs [33]. Wei et al. used a simple radical-induced strategy to synthesize In-CoO/CoP all-written FNS double-site porous structure heterojunctions, which provided an effective strategy to improve the electrocatalytic performance by interfacial coupling and increasing oxygen vacancies to achieve good oxygen reduction reaction activity and Zn-air battery performance [34]. Therefore, it is crucial yet difficult to design a hollow structure for the partial oxidation on the surface of CoP to accelerate the adsorption capacity of polysulfides and the catalytic conversion kinetics of S8 to Li2S, thus preventing the polysulfide shuttling. Here, we elaborately fabricate a hollow CoO/CoP core–shell heterostructure with a cubic structure and partially oxidized surface (denoted as CoO/CoP-Box) via using a series of stepwise calcinations, which acts as a model and a multifunctional catalyst modified on separators to induce interfacial charge modulation and expose more active sites, thereby to promote the adsorption and catalytic conversion ability of sulfur species. The CoO/CoP-Box core–shell heterostructure exhibits a hollow interior with high specific surface area, abundant mesoporous structures, and partially oxidized surface of CoO, which can expose abundant active sites for the adsorption of LiPSs and the catalytic conversion of sulfur species. And systematical static adsorption tests, permeation experiments, kinetic and thermodynamic analysis, and DFT calculations uncovered the macroscopic and microscopic mechanisms of CoO/CoP-Box for accelerated adsorption-electrocatalysis of bidirectional sulfur conversion. The CoO/CoP-Box with strong adsorption of LiPSs mainly originates that the in-situ formed hetero-interface generates the P-Co-O binding and induces the interfacial charge redistribution, so making the charge density of P-Co binds accumulated, while the charge density in Co-O binds is decreased, thereby activating the surface O active sites in Co-O layer for binding LiPSs via strong Li-O bonding, thereby strongly adsorbing with LiPSs. And the hetero-interface of CoO/CoP-Box promotes Li-ion and electron transfer and reduces the polarization, thereby leading to fast redox kinetics of Li2S. As a result, the Li-S cells with CoO/CoP-Box as a modified separator and traditional sulfur/carbon black (S/C) as a cathode display significant improvements in rate performance and long cycling stability compared with CoO and CoP-Box, which presents a large initial capacity of 1240 mA h g−1 and a long cycling stability with 300 cycles (∼60.1% capacity retention) at 0.5C. Impressively, the thick sulfur cathode (sulfur loading: 5.2 mg cm−2) gives a high initial areal capacity of 6.9 mA h cm−2 at 0.1C. Therefore, this work verifies an atomic-level mechanism understanding and an effective strategy to induce interfacial charge modulation and enhance active sites for designing efficient dual-directional Li-S catalysts towards high-performance LSBs via engineering hollow core–shell hetero-structure. And the developed model should be extended to other metallic compounds with such structure, such as metal chalcogenides, nitrides, etc, to promote bidirectional sulfur conversion. 2 Experimental Synthesis of hollow CoO/CoP-Box and preparation of its modified separators 2.1 Preparation of the Co2(CN)5NH2 cubes 896.4 mg cobaltous acetate and 1.588 g sodium citrate were dissolved in 120 mL deionized (DI) water to form solution A. 797.6 mg K3[Co(CN)6] were dissolved in 120 mL DI water to form solution B. The solutions A and B were mixed well under stirring and then left to stand for 24 h. Then, the precipitates were washed by anhydrous ethanol and DI water, and then dried to obtain Co2(CN)5NH2 cubes. 2.2 Preparation of the Co3O4 cube An appropriate amount of Co3[Co(CN)6]2 cubes were placed in a tube furnace and heated up to 400 °C with a rate of 5 °C min−1 under air atmosphere and kept at 400 °C for 2 h. The following was the course of the reaction: Co3[Co(CN)6]2 was calcined in a tube furnace at a rate of 5 °C min−1 and kept at the temperature for 2 hours to get Co3O4 cube. The reaction was as follows: Co3[Co(CN)6]2 • nH2O + O2 → Co3O4 + CO2 + N x O y + H2O 2.3 Preparation of the CoP cube (CoP-Box) A small amount of Co3O4 and NaH2PO2▪H2O was placed in two shallow crucibles, with NaH2PO2▪H2O was placed on the inlet side of the tube furnace and Co3O4 on the exhaust side, where the molar ratio of NaH2PO2▪H2O to Co3O4 was greater than 30:1. Then, the sample was heated to 350 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1 under a mixture of H2/Ar and held for 2 h. After cooling, a CoP-Box was obtained. 2.4 Preparation of partially oxidized hollow cubic CoP (CoO/CoP-Box) The as-synthesized hollow CoP-Box was warmed up to 80 °C in air and held for 4 h at a rate of 1 °C min−1 to partially oxidise the CoP-Box surface to obtain hollow CoO/CoP-Box. 2.5 Preparation of modified separators CoO/CoP-Box were firstly mixed with the conductive acetylene black (7 wt%) and polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF 3 wt%) in a certain ratio and then uniformly dispersed in the N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The slurry was then adsorbed and bonded to the surface of the separator by vacuum filtration, and finally dried under vacuum at 50 °C. The separator was then adsorbed and bonded to the surface of the separator by vacuum filtration and finally dried under vacuum at 50 °C to obtain a CoO/CoP-Box modified separator with a controlled loading of 0.3 mg cm−2. For comparison, CoP-Box modified separator was also prepared using the same method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Insight into the catalytic mechanism of the hollow CoO/CoP-Box core-shell heterostructure for accelerated conversion kinetics of sulfur species First, a hollow CoO/CoP-Box core–shell heterostructure was prepared using a series of stepwise calcinations. Here, the addition of surfactant and K3[Co(CN)6] into cobalt acetate results in the formation of relatively regular cubes. The cubes are oxidized at a low temperature (400 °C), and due to the temperature difference between the external surface and the internal surface, the Co3O4 tends to form agglomerated particles on the surface, thus forming a hollow Co3O4-Box. After that, the hollow cubic heterogeneous shell structure of CoO/CoP-Box is formed through phosphorization and partial oxidation processes (Fig. 1 a). Finally, the as-obtained hollow CoO/CoP-Box catalysts were modified on separators. As seen in Fig. 1(b), the modified separator effectively prevents LiPSs from passing through the separator to anode, providing a good defense against the LiPSs shuttling, thus effectively inhibiting LiPSs shuttling [35]. More importantly, the CoO/CoP-Box has a heterojunction made of CoO and CoP, which can efficiently transfer the electrons at a high speed from interface to interface, in addition to an oxide with a strong adsorption effect, a hollow structure can effectively buffer the volume expansion of sulfur and increase the specific surface area. Since more LiPSs are desorbed and nucleated on CoO/CoP-Box surface, abundant LiPSs are converted into Li2S on CoO/CoP-Box surface, which is the more intuitive effect. Afterward, we investigate the microscopic mechanisms, where the catalysts promote LiPS adsorption and decomposition (Fig. 1c). First, according to the optimized structural model of CoO/CoP heterojunction (Fig. S2) and its charge density difference (Fig. 1c), it can be seen that P-Co-O bonds were built, and the charge density in Co-P binds is accumulated, while the charge density in Co-O binds in is decreased, thereby leading to a strong Co-P bonding, while weakening the competing Co-O binding, namely forming a weaker Co-O binding compared to that in the optimized geometry models of only CoO or CoP. This result is further demonstrated using the calculation of Bader charge, that is, the average charge of O atoms in pure CoO was 6.8584 eV, whereas the average charge of O atoms in CoO of heterojunction was 6.8252 eV, so the average charge of O atoms in CoO of heterojunction is decreased. Due to the weaker Co-O bind energy (longer Co-O bond length), it facilitates the increase of the free moving electrons near O atom in Co-O, thus easily chemically binding with LiPSs via a strong Li-O binding, so facilitating the strong adsorption with LiPSs. The results are also demonstrated by a comparison of the Co-P and Co-O bond lengths in CoO and CoO/CoP heterojunction, as shown in Fig. 1(d) and Fig. S2 (XPS tests in Fig. 5d2 show the stronger Li-O bonding after adsorption). More importantly, more active sites are generated near the highly electronegative O, thus increasing the number of lattice active sites, which promotes LiPSs/Li2S catalysis and diffusion while reduces the activation energy of Li2S nucleation and dissolution [36]. The final results show that CoO/CoP heterojunction can effectively improve the adsorption ability with LiPSs, so effectively suppressing the LiPS shuttling, because the Li-O bond lengths of CoO/CoP/LiPSs (2.033 Å) are shorter than those of CoO/LiPSs (2.128 Å). Similarly, the same results were also obtained for the adsorption of Li2S (Fig. 1e and Fig. S3). Due to the formation of the heterojunction, the superior electronical conductivity remained and Li ions facilitate to diffuse on the surface of CoO/CoP, so the nucleation or decomposition energy barrier of Li2S is decreased, which makes Li2S easily converted to LiS and back to LiPSs, as demonstrated by DFT calculation for Li2S decomposition energy barrier. Briefly, the hollow CoO/CoP-Box core–shell heterojunction catalyst can effectively adsorb and catalyze the conversion of LiPSs, as demonstrated by the following thermodynamic and kinetic investigations, allowing the bidirectional catalytic conversion process of Li2S8 ↔ Li2S n ↔ Li2S to run smoothly and effectively. 3.2 Morphological and microstructural characterization of the hollow CoO/CoP-Box catalyst The morphology and microstructure of hollow CoO/CoP-Box were examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), as displayed in Fig. 2 . The SEM images of Co2(CN)5NH2, Co3O4, CoP-Box, and CoO/CoP-Box are depicted in Fig. 2(a-f), respectively. Co2(CN)5NH2 is a cubic compound with a side length of around 500 nm, a smooth surface, and a consistent size. Co2(CN)5NH2 owns a cubic shape, a uniform size, a smooth surface, and the edges with roughly 500 nm long. The hollow structure of the cube is depicted in Fig. 2(d). After a low temperature phosphating treatment, a CoP cubic structure is still presented, which gives a porous outside and hollow interior (Fig. 2e and f), and the hollow structure is still retained after the low-temperature oxidation treatment. The low-temperature oxidation process preserves the hollow structure, and the TEM image of CoO/CoP-Box clearly shows the hollow inner cavity of the nano-cubes (Fig. 2f). High-resolution (HR-) TEM image of CoO/CoP-Box (Fig. 2g) demonstrates two distinct lattice fringes, and two randomly chosen sites were Fourier transformed (Fig. 2h and i). The lattice spacing for the two sites was calculated to be 0.283 and 0.245 nm, respectively, corresponding to the (011) crystalline plane of CoP and the (111) crystalline plane of CoO. This further reveals that the CoO/CoP-Box catalyst was successfully synthesized, and the CoP-Box surface was partially oxidized. Fig. 2(g) shows a distinct boundary between CoP and CoO, demonstrating the emergence of a heterojunction between CoP and CoO. TEM results show that the tightly and atomically matched interfacial contact exists between CoO and CoP, so the hetero-structure is conductive to the enhanced trapping, diffusion, and conversion of LiPSs. In addition, Fig. 2(j) shows the elemental mapping image of CoO/CoP-Box, indicating that the Co, P and O elements are uniformly distributed in CoO/CoP-Box. Moreover, the Brauner-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area and pore-size distribution of CoO/CoP-Box and CoP-Box were also given in Fig. S1(b and c). The specific surface area of CoO/CoP-Box (96.6 m2/g) is a little higher than that of CoP-Box (63.2 m2/g), and they both exhibit abundant mesoporous and microporous structures. The results indicate that the hollow structure with partially oxidized surface can expose more active sites for the polysulfide adsorption and the catalytic conversion of sulfur species. The abundant mesoporous and microporous structures are conductive to providing more ion transport paths for Li ions during cycling. 3.3 Crystal structure and composition analysis of the hollow CoO/CoP-Box Fig. 3 (a) shows the XRD patterns of the Co3O4 precursor, the intense diffraction peaks indicate good crystallinity, where the typical diffraction peaks at 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.9°, 44.8°, 59.4°, 65.2° can be attributed to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), (440) crystal planes of Co3O4. The XRD patterns of CoP-Box and CoO/CoP-Box after low-temperature treatment (phosphorization and partial oxidation) are shown in Fig. 3(b). The distinct diffraction peaks at 2θ = 31.6°, 36.3°, 46.2°, 48.1°, 48.4°, and 56.8°, correspond to (011), (111), (112), (211), (202), and (301) planes of the orthorhombic phase CoP (JCPDS 29–0497), respectively [37]. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 36.5°, 42.4°, 61.5° correspond to (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of CoO (PDF No. 43–1004) [38]. In addition, the chemical composition and valence states of CoO/CoP-Box were also investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), as shown in Fig. 3(c). The characteristic peaks of Co, P, and O elements were clearly observed. And their characteristic peaks were finely swept and shown in Fig. 3(d-f), respectively. The characteristic peaks of high-resolution XPS spectrum of Co 2p 3/2 at 781.4 and 784.7 eV are attributed to Co3+ in CoP and Co2+ in CoO [38], indicating the presence of CoO and CoP in CoP/CoO-Box. The characteristic peaks at 778.6 eV (labeled as Co-P) and P 2p 3/2 (129.5 eV) are assigned to the binding energy of P and Co in CoO/CoP-Box, and the characteristic peak at 787.6 eV is a satellite peak of Co 2p 3/2, labeled Sat. The high-resolution P 2p spectrum has three distinct peaks at 133.5, 130.45, and 129.5 eV, corresponding to the PO exposed to air, P 2p 1/2, and P 2p 3/2, respectively, indicating the oxidation of the CoP surface [39]. This can also be verified by the high-resolution XPS spectrum of O 1 s, where the XPS spectrum in Fig. 3(f) can be deconvoluted into two parts, lattice O and adsorbed O, respectively. The evidence further demonstrates the CoP surface is partially oxidized. Besides, compared with the pure CoP-Box (Fig. S4), the peaks of CoP/CoO-Box at 778.5 eV (2 P3/2), 798.1 eV (2 P1/2), and P 2p shifted towards lower binding energy (Fig. S4a and b), indicating the introduction of CoO (in-situ formed CoO) on CoP surface induces the electronic structure change of Co 2p and P 2p, further demonstrating the existence of O-Co-P binding, which was also observed by HR-TEM images (Fig. 2 g-i) [40]. This should be attributable to that the introduction of O into the Co-P binds changes the electronic environment of Co and P elements. Moreover, the elemental mass contents of Co, P, and O in CoO/CoP-Box were also tested using an inductive coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP) and element analyzer (EA), which is approximately 67.92 wt% (Co), 29.67 wt% (P), and 2.41 wt% (O), corresponding to the atomic ratio of Co, P, and O is about 5:4:1, respectively, indicating that about 25% of CoP is oxidized to CoO, that is, the molar ratio (or atomic ratio) of CoO and CoP is 1:4. 3.4 Polysulfide adsorption and permeation experiments of the hollow CoO/CoP-Box modified separator in H-typed electrolytic cell The modified separator is made by mixing CoO/CoP-Box (90 wt%) with conductive carbon black (7 wt%) and PVDF (3 wt%) uniformly poured over a polypropylene (PP) separator by a vacuum filtration method, as displayed in Fig. 4 (a). The SEM image of a commercial PP separator (Fig. 4b) presents a porous structure with a smooth surface. After the modification of CoO/CoP-Box, the separator still retained the porous structure. In addition to having a large active surface area and more active catalysis, the hollow cubic structure also owns a strong affinity for LiPSs. A separator with good mechanical properties facilitates the large-scale practical production in LSBs. The CoO/CoP-Box modified separator displays a superior flexibility and foldability, which implies the high possibility in the applications of flexible devices (Fig. S5) [38]. Permeation experiments of LiPSs were carried out to verify the “interception” effect of the modified separator on polysulphide ions. Fig. 4(d and e) show the H-bottle with Li2S6 solution (left), blank solvent without Li2S6 (right), and CoO/CoP-Box or CoP-Box modified separator (middle), respectively. After the permeation for 12 hours, the color of the blank solvent (right) turns yellowish, demonstrating that a little amount of Li2S6 solution was permeated into the right blank solvent. However, the CoO/CoP-Box modified separator exhibits less Li2S6 penetration than that with CoP-Box modified separator (Fig. 4d1 and 4e1), demonstrating a better interception effect for CoO/CoP-Box modified separator. Additionally, as seen in Fig. 4(d2), there is a more noticeable difference between the two H-bottles after 24 h, with a significant difference between the two sides of the CoO/CoP-Box modified separator. This difference suggests that the CoO/CoP-Box modified separator effectively blocks the Li2S6 penetration while allowing the electrolyte to completely permeate to the right side. Additionally, the color of the solution on the right side of H-bottle with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator is far paler than that on the right side of H-bottle with CoP-Box modified separator (Fig. 4e2), indicating that the CoO/CoP-Box modified separator can effectively capture LiPSs and restrict the LiPSs shuttling to the anode due to its strong adsorption ability. Although the abundant LiPSs were absorbed on the surface of CoO/CoP-Box modified separator, the porous structure of CoO/CoP-Box is still maintained well (see Fig. 4g1 and h1), providing a good channel for Li+ transport. According to the aforementioned above, the CoO/CoP-Box modified separator has a significant absorption ability for LiPSs and high structural stability, thus effectively preventing LiPSs shuttling. 3.5 Adsorption and catalytic conversion analysis of sulfur species for the hollow CoO/CoP-Box catalyst To confirm the benefits of the hollow CoO/CoP-Box catalysts for the electrocatalysis and adsorption of LiPSs in LSBs. Li2S6 static adsorption studies were used to confirm the adsorption ability of CoO/CoP-Box initially. The same quantity of CoP-Box and CoO/CoP-Box were put in a Li2S6 solution with the same volume and concentration, as shown in Fig. 5 (a). After 3 hours, the color of the solution with CoO/CoP-Box is considerably different from the solution with CoP-Box, showing that CoO/CoP-Box own the stronger adsorption ability for Li2S6 than CoP-Box. The UV–vis absorption spectra of the three solutions were analyzed independently after sufficient static adsorption for a long enough period of time, as illustrated in Fig. 5(b). The characteristic peaks of S6 2- were observed at 265, 300, and 350 nm, and the intensity of the characteristic peaks for the two materials varied as a result of the differences in their adsorption ability. And the intensity of the characteristic peak of the Li2S6 solution after adsorption by CoP-Box is higher than that of CoO/CoP-Box, indicating that a stronger adsorption ability of CoO/CoP-Box for Li2S6 than that of CoP-Box, which is consistent with the foregoing observations (Fig. 5b). Additionally, XPS was used to analyze the surface chemical composition of CoO/CoP-Box with Li2S6 adsorption (CoO/CoP-Box/Li2S6). The high-resolution XPS spectra of Co 2p 3/2 and O 1s in CoO/CoP-Box/Li2S6 in comparison to before adsorption are shown in Fig. 5(c1,c2, d1, d2), respectively. The Co-P peak was shifted. In the high-resolution XPS spectrum of O 1s, the characteristic peaks at 533.2 and 530 eV were clearly observed (Fig. 5d2) [39], which may be partially attributed to the Li-O bonding, indicating a strong chemical bonding between CoO/CoP-Box and Li2S6, which leads to its higher absorption ability for Li2S6. The improved cycling performance of LSBs is due to the higher chemisorption, which effectively retains the LiPSs on the cathode side and prevents them from diffusing to the anode side. Based on the aforementioned results, the CoO/CoP-Box catalyst demonstrates a good adsorption capacity and catalytic activity in the capture and catalysis of polysulfides. Using Li2S6 as the electrolyte, a symmetric cell with two identical electrodes was constructed to systematically explore the improvement of the catalyst on the conversion of the liquid to liquid conversion kinetics of LiPSs, which is to further validate the catalytic ability for LiPSs. As seen in Fig. 5(e), CoO/CoP-Box has a higher peak current yet a smaller peak potential difference than those of CoP-Box at the same sweep speed, confirming the smaller internal polarization of the symmetric cell with CoO/CoP-Box, further indicating that CoO/CoP-Box has a better catalytic ability for the LiPSs conversion. To further demonstrate the superiority of CoO/CoP-Box heterostructure toward the LiPSs conversion, Li2S precipitation experiments were conducted [41–43]. Generally, the nucleation and growth of Li2S depends on the reactive interfaces of catalysts. Therefore, Li2S deposition experiments on different surfaces were investigated to further confirm the synergistic effect of CoO/CoP-Box heterostructure. The transformation of polysulphides into Li2S and back into polysulphides is represented by the nucleation (Fig. 5f and Fig. S6a-c) and dissolution (Fig. 5h and Fig. S7a-c) processes of Li2S. The CoO/CoP-Box electrode greatly accelerates the Li2S nucleation (678 s) and dissolution (870 s), compared to those of CoP-Box (872 s, 1570 s), and Blank (2207 s, 1832 s), as seen by the time for occurrence current peak in potentiostatic discharging curves (Fig. 5g and i). Additionally, the Faraday’s law was used to determine the Li2S nucleation and dissolution capacity on CoO/CoP-Box, CoP-Box, and Blank electrodes. Fig. 3(h and k) illustrates the calculation results, demonstrating that the CoO/CoP-Box electrode has the highest nucleation capacity (96.8 mA h g−1) and dissolution capacity (204.72 mA h g−1) of Li2S compared to those of the CoP-Box (88.83, 192.41 mA h g−1) and Blank electrodes (50, 78.89 mA h g−1). This indicates that the CoO/CoP-Box catalyst significantly promotes the conversion rate from LiPSs to Li2S and Li2S to LiPSs, thereby improving the reaction kinetics of Li2S nucleation and dissolution, which is beneficial to increasing the utilization of active sulfur in practical applications, thus improving its specific capacity and electrochemical performance in LSBs. 3.6 Activation energy analysis of Li-S cells with hollow CoO/CoP-Box catalyst modified separator To gain insight into the catalytic mechanism of the CoO/CoP-Box catalysts, the activation energy (Ea ) of the redox process of LiPSs was calculated using the Arrhenius equation (j = A × e - E a / RT ), where E a is the activation energy, R is the gas constant, A is a pre-exponential factor, and T is temperature [44,45]. Fig. S8(a-c) displays the CV curves of the Li-S cells with blank, CoP-Box, or CoO/CoP-Box modified separator at different temperatures (30, 40 and 50 °C), respectively. The control cell showed broad peaks at both the anodic and cathodic scans, while the cells with CoP-Box and CoO/CoP-Box modified separator showed progressively narrower half-peak widths in turn, particularly, CoO/CoP-Box displayed the smallest half-peak width and the largest response current, indicating rapid charge transport and accelerated redox kinetics of polysulfides. Considering that the electrochemical conversion (Li2S4 to Li2S) at 2.1 V contributes most of the capacity (Peak C), Peak C and Peak A (Li2S to Li2S n ) were chosen to calculate the activation energy of the corresponding electrochemical conversion reaction. Fig. S8(d) shows the fitted lines of peak current and temperature for the three cells. For Peak A and Peak C, the activation energy of the cells with blank (Peak A: 22.65 kJ mol−1, Peak C: 28.23 kJ mol−1) and CoP-Box (Peak A: 12.69 kJ mol−1, Peak C: 14.43 kJ mol−1) is higher than those with CoO/CoP-Box (Peak A: 10.02 kJ mol−1, Peak C: 11.73 kJ mol−1), indicating that CoO/CoP-Box catalyst can greatly expedite the liquid–solid and solid–liquid transformations, thus significantly reducing the nucleation and decomposition energy barrier of Li2S (Fig. 5j). Fig. 5(k) shows more visual curves that CoO/CoP-Box heterojunction catalyst can effectively reduce the activation energy. By promoting the reaction kinetics of the conversion of soluble Li2S n to Li2S, the concentration of Li2S n in the electrolyte is reduced, eliminating the driving force for the shuttle effect and effectively blocking the LiPSs shuttling. In addition, the full utilization of the active sulfur can effectively improve the charge/discharge capacity and cycle stability of LSBs. 3.7 DFT simulation analysis of CoO, CoP, and CoO/CoP DFT calculations were further employed to elucidate the interfacial interaction between LiPSs and CoO, CoP-Box, or CoO/CoP-Box. To begin with, we investigated the density of states (TDOS) of the three materials in order to reveal the electronic conductivity of the CoO/CoP-Box heterostructure, as shown in Fig. S10(a-c). Compared with CoO and CoP, there is no band gap across the Fermi level for CoO/CoP-Box and the electronic state near the Fermi level is higher on the CoO/CoP-Box heterostructure. This result indicates that the conductivity of CoO/CoP-Box approaches that of CoP, reflecting the advantage of the hetero-structure. Further insight was gained into the reasons for the good adsorption energy of the CoO/CoP hetero-structure. Fig. 6 (a-c) shows the optimized adsorption structures of CoO, CoP, and CoO/CoP with adsorption of Li2S6, charge density difference, and their two-dimensional slices, where it can be seen that there is a lot of charge accumulation between Li and O, suggesting that the formation of strong Li-O bonding. The adsorption models of Li2S and Li2S6 with CoO and CoO/CoP were shown in Fig. 6(a) and Fig. S9(a), respectively. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the charge accumulation of Li-O binds in CoO/CoP/Li2S6 sample is the highest among the three materials, leading to the strongest Li-O bonding, which is clearly verified by the 2D cross-sectional images (Fig. 6c). Similarly, it also forms strong bonding with Li2S, which gives the highest binding energy with Li2S in the three materials (Fig. S8b and c). This suggests that CoO/CoP-Box hetero-structure facilitates the absorption with Li ions, thus resulting in a high Li2S adsorption energy. As seen in Fig. 6(e) and Table S1, the calculated binding energies of CoO, CoP, and CoO/CoP with Li2S were 5.49, 4.02, and 6.24 eV, respectively. Similarly, the calculated binding energies of CoO, CoP, and CoO/CoP with Li2S6 were 4.92, 5.48, and 6.33 eV, respectively [46,47], suggesting a strong chemisorption of CoO/CoP-Box hetero-structure with sulphur species. Additionally, CoO/CoP has the lowest decomposition energy barrier, as seen in Fig. 6(e). The specific decomposition route is also shown in Fig. 6(e). Since Li and O are more tightly bound, the Li-S bond will be relatively easy to decompose away, resulting in a lower decomposition energy barrier of CoO/CoP than that of CoO. 3.8 Electrochemical performance of the Li-S cells with CoO/CoP-Box modified separators The polysulphides may be effectively intercepted and converted thanks to the strong adsorption and high catalytic activity, so the Li-S cells with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator should be able to significantly suppress the polysulphide shuttling and improve the cycle stability [14]. Therefore, the practical electrochemical performance of Li-S cells with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator, along with the comparison of CoP-Box and blank modified separators was tested, separately. First, the kinetics of the sulphur redox processes were investigated by cyclic voltammetry, as shown in Fig. 7 (a). The two cathodic peaks of the CV curves correspond to the conversion of solid sulphur to soluble polysulphides (solid–liquid) and the conversion of soluble LiPSs to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S (liquid–solid), while the anodic peak is attributed to the oxidation of Li2S2/Li2S. As the liquid–solid conversion contributes the majority of the capacity in LSBs, the analysis focused on the cathodic peak near 2.0 V. It is clearly observed in Fig. 7(a) at 0.1 mV s−1, the Li-S cell with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator displayed the highest cathodic peak current (1.12 mA) and peak potential (2.01 V) compared to CoP-Box (0.94 mA and 1.995 V) and the blank (0.59 mA and 1.963 V), which facilitates to enhance the reaction kinetics [48–50]. In addition, the sharpest cathodic and anodic peaks demonstrated the fastest reaction rate and kinetics, thus demonstrating the best catalytic activity of CoO/CoP-Box heterojunction [51]. The Nyquist plot of the fresh cell with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator is shown in Fig. S11(a). A semicircle appears in the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the cells with CoP-Box and CoO/CoP-Box modified separators, and the semicircle diameter of CoO/CoP-Box is slightly smaller than that of CoP-Box, meaning that the CoO/CoP-Box can reduce the charge transfer, thus providing better electrochemical kinetics. The long cycle life of the battery is more reflective to the catalytic ability of a catalyst. Fig. 7(b) and Fig. S11b depict the GCD curves after the first and 300th cycle, respectively. The Li-S cell with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator exhibited the lowest polarization both after the first (139 mv) and 300th cycle (255 mv) among the three cells (Fig. S11b gives the same result), demonstrating the CoO/CoP-Box gives the fast electron transfer and sulfur catalytic conversion ability. Besides, the comparative rate performance of Li-S cells with CoO/CoP-Box, CoP-Box, and blank modified separators was evaluated at different rates. As shown in Fig. 7(c), the discharge specific capacity decreases significantly with increasing rate, and the cell with CoO/CoP-Box presents the largest discharge specific capacity among the three cells. The specific capacities of the cell with CoO/CoP-Box were 1248.1, 1055.6, 910.1, 720.7, 597.1, and 510 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 5C, respectively. When the rate returned to 0.1C, the discharge specific capacity retained at 1115.9 mA h g−1. This discharge capacity is substantially higher than those of the cells with CoP-Box and Blank. The superior rate performance should be attributed to the fast electron transfer and sulfur catalytic conversion ability for the CoO/CoP-Box catalyst. Fig. 7(d) shows the comparative long cycle performance of Li-S cells with CoO/CoP-Box, CoP-Box, and blank modified separators at 0.1C. The initial discharge specific capacities are 1292.5, 1195.1, and 1073.4 mA h g−1. After 300 cycles, their capacity retention are 58.4% (753.9 mA h g−1), 40.4% (513.0 mA h g−1), and 11.6% (125.5 mA h g−1), respectively. The superior capacity retention implies that CoO/CoP-Box has a good catalytic ability for the redox conversion of polysulfides and a good cycling stability for the inhibition of polysulfide shuttling. The long-cycle performance of Li-S cells with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator at a higher rate of 0.5C was further investigated. As shown in Fig. 7(e), its initial discharge capacity is 1240 mA h g−1 and retains at 745.3 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles, with a 60.1% capacity retention (only 0.133% capacity decay per cycle), demonstrating a superior long cycle stability at 0.5C. Even at the higher current density of 1C, it still maintains good cycling stability with a 56.2% capacity retention after 300 cycles (Fig. S12). Besides, to demonstrate the practical application, the electrochemical performance at a high sulfur loading was also tested. As shown in Fig. 7(f), at a high sulfur loading of 5.2 mg cm−2, the thick Li-S cells with CoO/CoP-Box modified separators exhibit a high initial areal capacity of 6.9 mA h cm−2 and remain at 4.6 mA h cm−2 after 50 cycles at 0.1C. Even at a low electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio of 4.8 μL mg-1 s, the areal capacities of the thick Li-S cell still remain about 88.4% retention compared to those in the routine E/S ratio with 15 μL mg−1, indicating a potential practicability in a lean electrolyte. The result demonstrates, even at high sulfur loading, CoO/CoP-Box modified separators also give a superior performance, verifying a good intercept effect for abundant LiPSs in the high-sulfur-loaded cathode. Besides, the sulfuration and phase transition of the CoO/CoP-Box after cycling were investigated using ex-situ XRD and XPS (Fig. S13), respectively. The results demonstrate that the CoO/CoP-Box sample modified on separator did not obviously generate the sulfuration and phase transition after cycling, and the O-Co-P bonds were also well remained during cycling (the detailed descriptions see Fig. S13) [52]. Table S2 shows the comparative performance of Li-S cells with different catalysts modified separators in recent years, which gives the comparable, even superior performance in cycling stability and areal capacity. The results further confirm that the hollow CoO/CoP-Box heterostructure can promote the bidirectional sulfur-catalyzed conversion, thus inhibiting the LiPS shuttling and improving the sulfur utilization in LSBs. 4 Conclusions Overall, we have successfully fabricated a hollow CoO/CoP-Box core–shell heterostructure catalyst with cubic structures modified on separators. The CoO/CoP-Box effectively enhanced the capture ability with LiPSs while reducing the activation energy of solid–liquid and liquid–solid conversions, as verified by static adsorption tests, permeation experiments, kinetic and thermodynamic analysis, and DFT calculations. The superior electrochemical performance of the hollow heterostructure should be attributed to the following aspects: (1) hollow core–shell heterostructure with high specific surface area can expose more active sites for the adsorption of LiPSs and catalytic conversion of sulfur species, and provide abundant pore structure for Li+ transport. (2) in-situ formed core–shell hetero-structure formed P-Co-O binding and induces the charge redistribution at the hetero-interface, thus activating the surface O active sites for binding LiPSs via strong Li-O bonding, thus strongly adsorbing with LiPSs. Meanwhile, the strong Li-O bonding weakens the competing Li-S bonding in LiPSs or Li2S adsorbed on CoO/CoP-Box surface, thus facilitating the breakage of Li-S binds during the nucleation and dissolution of Li2S, further decreasing Li2S nucleation and dissolution activation energy. (3) Despite the formation of CoO layer on CoP surface, the CoO/CoP-Box still retained superior electrical conductivity like CoP, further facilitating the electron transfer during cycling. Therefore, this work, taking the hollow CoO/CoP core–shell heterostructure as the model, confirmed that the hollow core–shell heterostructure catalyst can induce the interfacial charge modulation and provide abundant pore structure and active sites for accelerated adsorption-electrocatalysis of bidirectional sulfur conversion, thus designing efficient bidirectional Li-S catalysts for high-performance LSBs. And the developed model should be extended to other metallic compounds with such structure, such as metal chalcogenides, nitrides, etc, to promote bidirectional sulfur conversion. coredata.dc:description: Severe polysulfide shuttling and sluggish sulfur redox kinetics significantly decrease sulfur utilization and cycling stability in lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs). Herein, we develop a hollow CoO/CoP-Box core–shell heterostructure as a model and multifunctional catalyst modified on separators to induce interfacial charge modulation and expose more active sites for promoting the adsorption and catalytic conversion ability of sulfur species. Theoretical and experimental findings verify that the in-situ formed core–shell hetero-interface induces the formation of P-Co-O binding and charge redistribution to activate surface O active sites for binding lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) via strong Li-O bonding, thus strongly adsorbing with LiPSs. Meanwhile, the strong Li-O bonding weakens the competing Li-S bonding in LiPSs or Li2S adsorbed on CoO/CoP-Box surface, plus the hollow heterostructure provides abundant active sites and fast electron/Li+ transfer, so reducing Li2S nucleation/dissolution activation energy. As expected, LSBs with CoO/CoP-Box modified separator and traditional sulfur/carbon black cathode display a large initial capacity of 1240 mA h g−1 and a long cycling stability with 300 cycles (∼60.1% capacity retention) at 0.5C. Impressively, the thick sulfur cathode (sulfur loading: 5.2 mg cm−2) displays a high initial areal capacity of 6.9 mA h cm−2. This work verifies a deep mechanism understanding and an effective strategy to induce interfacial charge modulation and enhance active sites for designing efficient dual-directional Li-S catalysts via engineering hollow core–shell hetero-structure.
